value: Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions

This Atlas was inspired by a series of conversations about the science of emotion between the Dalai Lama and Dr. Paul Ekman. Created in collaboration with Stamen Design and Paul’s daughter, Dr. Eve Ekman, the Atlas of Emotions is an interactive visual journey through the world of emotions.
Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions
The first step to managing your emotions is learning to identify and describe what you are feeling.
This Atlas is a visual tool to build your emotion vocabulary. The goal is to increase choice in what we become emotional about and how we respond.

There are 5 emotions to explore. Discover more about each emotion as you interact with the shapes. Navigate by clicking down, left and right.

Consider each emotion and reflect on how it relates to your lived experience.
The atlas: a new kind of map

The Atlas was commissioned by the Dalai Lama to create a scientifically-based road map to emotional self-awareness. Dr. Paul Ekman and his daughter, Eve Ekman, based the Atlas on a study they conducted.

The scientists surveyed in the study agreed that these five emotions are the most universally felt:
Pick any emotion and start exploring.
Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions
The Atlas is an interactive tool that builds your vocabulary of emotions and illuminates your emotional world.
The goal is to gain greater control over what triggers your emotions and how you respond.
The first step towards emotional awareness is learning to identify and describe how you are feeling, and why.

The Dalai Lama imagined "a map of our emotions to develop a calm mind." He asked his longtime friend and renowned emotion scientist Dr. Paul Ekman to realize his idea. Ekman took on the creation of the Atlas alongside his daughter, Eve Ekman, a second-generation emotion researcher and teacher. The Dalai Lama requested the Atlas represent the science of Emotions from what researchers have learned from the psychological study of emotion.

Most emotions researchers agree on these five Universal Emotions: emotions that all humans, no matter where or how we were raised, have in common. The movement of the shapes reflects the fluid nature of emotions – the way their strength and frequency varies from moment to moment. Select an emotion to learn more.
Most emotions researchers agree on these five Universal Emotions: emotions that all humans, no matter where or how we were raised, have in common. Tap on an emotion to start exploring.
Here we explore different states and intensities within one emotion family.
LHAMO can be felt mildly, extremely, or somewhere in between. Tap on the shapes above to learn about a few of the states that we can experience.
Select a shape to learn about some of the states we can experience.

We respond to emotional states with our actions. Our responses to the same emotion may differ depending on the circumstances. We may have a primary, more immediate response, and a secondary more thoughtful response. Any response can be constructive and helpful to ourselves, others and the situation, or destructive and not helpful.
We respond to emotional states with our actions. Tap on the shapes to learn about the possible actions resulting from LHAMO.
In this state, this action is CONSTRUCTIVE. It’s a useful response to the emotion.
In this state, this action is AMBIGUOUS. It could either be a useful response to the emotion or it could cause harm.
In this state, this action is DESTRUCTIVE. It could cause harm.
Select a shape to learn about some of the states we can experience. Then select an action to learn more.
A trigger is something around us or in our own minds that causes us to feel an emotion. Select the labels to learn about triggering LHAMO.
A trigger is something around us or in our own minds that causes us to feel an emotion. Tap on the labels to learn about triggering LHAMO.
Some triggers are hardwired and universal for everyone, other triggers are learned from the world around us and our individual experience.
Past personal experience determines whether or not a learned trigger makes us feel emotional. Universal triggers break through regardless.
Emotion is our automatic response to being triggered. The state of emotion we feel and the actions we take often happen without our realizing why.
This is an example of a universal trigger. Everyone has the same universal triggers – we're born with them. They affect us more intensely than learned triggers.
This is an example of a learned trigger. Some learned triggers are shared across a culture, while others are highly personal and created by individual experiences.
Moods are longer-lasting cousins of an emotion that cause us to feel the related emotion repeatedly without any clear trigger. Select the shape to learn more.
Moods are longer-lasting cousins of an emotion that cause us to feel the related emotion repeatedly without any clear trigger. Tap on the shape to learn more.

The Atlas of Emotion was commissioned by the Dalai Lama, his purpose is “ In order to find the new world we needed a map, and in order for us to find a calm mind we need a map of our emotions”. The simple, but not easy, goal of this Atlas is to help us be aware of our emotions. Awareness of our emotions means understanding how they are triggered, what they feel like and how we respond. Awareness itself is a strategy, it helps us understand our emotion experiences. We do not want to get rid of our emotions, we want strategies that help us respond in helpful, constructive ways.

The Atlas of Emotion was commissioned by the Dalai Lama, his purpose is “ In order to find the new world we needed a map, and in order for us to find a calm mind we need a map of our emotions”. The simple, but not easy, goal of this Atlas is to help us be aware of our emotions. Awareness of our emotions means understanding how they are triggered, what they feel like and how we respond. Awareness itself is a strategy, it helps us understand our emotion experiences. We do not want to get rid of our emotions, we want strategies that help us respond in helpful, constructive ways.
To learn more about emotions, click on “More Information” in the bottom right corner.
Our emotions unfold on a timeline. The timeline begins with a trigger that initiates an emotional experience and ultimately results in a response.
Try choosing different emotions from the list below the timeline.
Notice how the same trigger can lead to a different response, depending on the emotion we feel.
The trigger occurs in a context:
Our worldview, which is influenced by our prior experiences, personal history and inherited universal scripts about important events
The emotional experience that is triggered includes subjective feelings and physical sensations. These color our perception of a situation.
We have a choice in how we respond, although sometimes it's hard to feel in control of our responses. Some responses are more constructive than others.
Why is it hard to stay aware?
When an emotion is triggered we are in the grip of that emotion, which limits our ability to think clearly and choose how we respond.
As time passes, we gain some clarity and the ability to make a thoughtful choice.
With awareness we can pause before we respond and choose a response that best serves our goals.
You can select each piece of the timeline and learn how researchers make sense of an emotional episode. Then, continue to the Experience section to see how they map our emotional experiences.
The context, which influences the way we experience the emotion
An event that happens in the world or in our own mind
How we see the world, which is a result of our personal history and universal scripts; these scripts are outlines of repeated emotional experiences, some inherited, some acquired.
The automatic bodily sensations of our emotion
Our combined physical and mental changes
The immediate felt experience of our emotion
A response that helps you in your goals
A response that gets in the way of your goals
A response that could be helpful or unhelpful — sometimes we aren't sure
We are making an atlas for children! If you would like to support this project, please visit our page on
We get angry when something blocks us or when we think we're being treated unfairly.
We feel anger when we are mentally or physically blocked. Anger varies in strength and frequency in our lives.

Anger contains both annoyance and fury. The intensity of these states varies: We can feel mild or strong annoyance, but we can only feel intense fury. All states of anger are triggered by a feeling of being blocked in our progress.
Very mild anger caused by a nuisance or inconvenience.
A response to repeated failures to overcome an obstacle.
A tendency to engage in disagreements.
Anger caused by a repeated or strong nuisance.
Desire to retaliate after one is hurt.

For example, we might suppress our feelings of frustration at work, but scream and yell to express our frustration with a family member. Suppressing our frustration can be constructive in cases where it helps us avoid arguments, but destructive if we are being hurt by not speaking up for ourselves.
Verbally oppose in a manner intended to escalate the disagreement.
Disparage the other person in an offensive or hurtful way that is likely to escalate the conflict rather than resolve it.
Take action to make someone or something weaker or less effective, usually in a secret or gradual way.
Disagree in a manner that may escalate the conflict.
Lose control of one's speech; speak loudly and possibly at a higher pitch.
Try to avoid feeling or acting upon the emotion that is being experienced.
Take indirect actions that have an angry undercurrent.
Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Interference with action or locomotion are examples.
Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Being wrongfully accused or put down by an authority figure are examples.
Being put down by an authority figure
Predisposed to becoming angry, easily provoked.
a friend gets upset with you
Our fear of danger lets us anticipate threats to our safety.
We feel fear when our safety or wellbeing is threatened. Fear varies in strength and frequency in our lives.

Fear contains both anxiety and terror. The intensity of these states varies: We can feel mild or strong anxiety, but we can only feel intense terror. All states of fear are triggered by feeling a threat of harm.
Anticipation of the possibility of danger.
Fear of an anticipated or actual threat and uncertainty about one's ability to cope with it.
Uncertainty as to whether there is a danger.
A response to the inability to reduce danger.
A mixture of fear, disgust, and shock.

For example, we might avoid feeling anxiety at work, but ruminate on our anxiety at home. Avoiding anxiety can be constructive if it helps us give a presentation to a room full of colleagues, but destructive if it prevents us from confronting our difficult relationship with our boss.
Physically or mentally leave the scene of the threat.
Either physically stay away from the threat or keep oneself from thinking about it.
Hold back in doubt or indecision, often momentarily.
Become incapable of acting or speaking.
Lose control of one's speech; cry out in a loud and high voice.
Obsessively think about a past emotional experience.
Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Snake-like shapes and sudden loss of gravity are examples.
Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Public speaking, thunder, and the threat of losing one’s job are examples.
Anxious that something bad will happen, on edge.
a friend gets angry with you
Feeling disgusted by what is toxic helps us to avoid being poisoned, physically or socially.
We feel disgust when faced with something toxic or unpleasant. Disgust varies in strength and frequency in our lives.

Disgust contains both dislike and loathing. The intensity of these states varies: We can feel mild or strong dislike, but we can only feel intense loathing. All states of disgust are triggered by the feeling that something is toxic.
An impulse to avoid something disgusting.
Reaction to a bad taste, smell, thing or idea. Can be literal or metaphorical.
Strong distaste for something, often a concept or idea.
A mixture of disgust and loathing.
A mixture of intense disgust and hatred.
Intense disgust focused on a person. Intense disgust focused on oneself is called self-loathing.

For example, we might avoid feeling aversion towards others at work, but find ourselves feeling aversion towards individuals we read about in the news. Avoiding aversion can be constructive in overcoming bias, but can be destructive if it leads us to get involved with a harmful person.
Physically or mentally leave the scene of what is triggering the disgust.
Either physically stay away from whatever is triggering the disgust or keep oneself from thinking about it.
Respond to feelings of disgust by throwing up.
Treat someone as though he or she is not a human being; deprive someone of human qualities, personality or spirit.
Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Anything in decay or coming out of the body are examples.
Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Unfamiliar religious customs and eating insects or raw meat are examples.
Anything coming out of the body
Fans of an opposing sports team
you are having a hard day
a friend gets angry with you
Sadness is a response to loss, and feeling sad allows us to take a timeout and show others that we need support.
We feel sadness when we lose something valuable. Sadness varies in strength and frequency in our lives.

Sadness contains both disappointment and despair. The intensity of these states varies: We can feel mild or strong disappointment, but we can only feel intense despair. All states of sadness are triggered by a feeling of loss.
A feeling that expectations are not being met.
The belief that nothing can be done.
Sadness that makes it hard to think clearly.
A response to repeated failures to accomplish something: the belief that it can't be done.
The realization that one cannot make a situation better or easier.
The belief that nothing good will happen.
The loss of hope that a bad situation will improve or change.
A feeling of distress and sadness, often caused by a loss.

For example, we might withdraw from feeling helpless in public, but seek comfort at home. Withdrawing from feeling helpless can be constructive to overcoming intense grief, but destructive if we don't seek support when we need it.
Seek help or support from others.
Either physically stay away from what is triggering the sadness or keep oneself from thinking about it.
Obsessively think about the emotional experience.
Express grief for one's loss through actions, dress and speech.
Feel embarrassed by one's feelings about the loss.
Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Losing or being rejected by a loved one are examples.
Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Feeling left out or experiencing a perceived loss of status are examples.
Not being invited to a party
An enduring feeling of discouragement or disappointment.
a friend gets angry with you
Enjoyment describes the many good feelings that arise from experiences both novel and familiar.
We feel enjoyment when we experience novelty or comfort. Enjoyment varies in strength and frequency in our lives.

Enjoyment contains both peace and ecstasy. The intensity of these states varies: We can feel mild or strong peacefulness, but we can only feel intense ecstasy. All states of enjoyment are triggered by feeling connection and/or sensory pleasure.
Enjoyment derived through one of the five physical senses: sight, sound, touch, taste and smell.
A warm, uplifting feeling that people experience when they see acts of human goodness, kindness and compassion. Also called elevation.
Light, playful feelings of enjoyment and good humor.
When something expected to be unpleasant, especially the threat of harm, is avoided or comes to an end.
Enjoyment of helping to relieve another person's suffering.
Enjoyment of the misfortunes of another person, usually a rival.
Enjoyment of meeting a difficult challenge (an Italian word).
Joyful pride in the accomplishments of one's children or mentees (a Yiddish word).
Deep pleasure and satisfaction derived from one's own achievements or the achievements of an associate.
An experience of something that is very surprising, beautiful, amazing or hard to believe.
An experience of ease and contentment.
Rapturous delight. A state of very great happiness, nearly overwhelming.

For example, we might exclaim to express our feeling of amusement among friends, but experience our amusement quietly while alone. Expressing amusement by exclaiming can be constructive as means of sharing enjoyment, but destructive if it's in response to making fun of someone.
Attempt to increase the enjoyable feelings.
Continue to do what is necessary to continue the enjoyable feelings.
Enjoy others’ envy of your state of enjoyment.
Share one's feelings of enjoyment with others without a desire to cause jealousy.
Appreciate the good feelings around an experience completely, especially by dwelling on them.
Allow oneself to fully experience the pleasure of good feelings.
Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Social interaction and experiencing nature are examples.
Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Spending time with family or visiting places from one’s youth are examples.
a friend gets angry with you

The Atlas of Emotions is an interactive tool designed to build emotional awareness. The site invites you to visualize, identify and explore five primary emotions (and their related feeling states, actions, triggers and moods) in order to gain a better understanding of how they influence our lives. Although we can’t always choose what emotions to feel or when to feel them, by building emotional awareness, it may be possible to choose how we respond to what we’re feeling. 

The Atlas began when the Dalai Lama asked prominent emotion researcher Paul Ekman to create a map of the emotions that could help people learn to have more constructive emotional experiences. Ekman, an expert in the field, had previously consulted on a wide range of emotion-related projects, including the popular Pixar film Inside Out. With his daughter, scholar Eve Ekman, he created the Atlas of Emotions in response to the Dalai Lama’s request.

The Atlas of Emotions is an interactive tool designed to build emotional awareness. The site invites you to visualize, identify and explore five primary emotions (and their related feeling states, actions, triggers and moods) in order to gain a better understanding of how they influence our lives. Although we can’t always choose what emotions to feel or when to feel them, by building emotional awareness, it may be possible to choose how we respond to what we’re feeling. 

The Atlas began when the Dalai Lama asked prominent emotion researcher Paul Ekman to create a map of the emotions that could help people learn to have more constructive emotional experiences. Ekman, an expert in the field, had previously consulted on a wide range of emotion-related projects, including the popular Pixar film Inside Out. With his daughter, scholar Eve Ekman, he created the Atlas of Emotions in response to the Dalai Lama’s request.

Paul Ekman is a renowned American psychologist who pioneered the field of emotion research. After teaching at UCSF for 40 years and collaborating with partners as diverse as law enforcement agencies and the Dalai Lama, he now runs a private training company. 
 
Eve Ekman is a post-doctoral scholar at UCSF’s Osher Center for Integrative Medicine. As a teacher trainer for Cultivating Emotional Balance (CEB), an emotion-regulation and meditation intervention, Eve adapts CEB to train care providers in various fields.

Stamen Design was founded by Eric Rodenbeck in 2001. Since then, the studio has grown to a staff of 12 and established a reputation for its expertise in creating compelling interactive design and data visualization projects. Stamen is neither a research and development lab nor a traditional design firm, but something in between: a place where collaboration is valued, good ideas can come from anywhere and results are paramount.
Improve your well being with daily emotional balance training.

A brand new app, EmoTrak, is under development by Dr. Eve Ekman and collaborators. Sign up below to be the first to find out about the release of this science based emotional training app.
true in mail column indicates that it will include hardcoded subscribe link

Dr. Eve Ekman is a University of California San Francisco postdoctoral fellow studying burnout and emotional well being. Dr. Ekman has been developing and evaluating EmoTrak to support health care providers. The app is a self assessment tool to investigate emotion triggers, experiences and responses. It also provides brief emotion focused meditations and feedback on your emotional profile.
